metadata.case_name: State of Madhya Pradesh v. Revashankar

facts.text: Ganga Ram instituted suit No. 1383 of 1952 in court of Additional City Civil Judge, Indore, for ejectment and arrears of rent against Revashankar.
Uma Shankar Chaturvedi advised Ganga Ram to sign name of his wife Chandra Mukhi Bai on plaint and vakalatnama, though she did not sign.
Chandra Mukhi Bai filed application for permission to prosecute her husband for forgery. Other tenants filed application with allegations against Revashankar.

On June 29, 1953, Revashankar filed complaint against five persons under s.500 IPC, verified July 13, 1953, registered as Criminal Case No. 637 of 1953 before Additional District Magistrate N.K. Acharya, Indore.
Kulkarni appeared for complainant Revashankar; accused appeared through Mohan Singh and Uma Shankar Chaturvedi on August 8, 1953. Objection raised to Kulkarni's appearance as he was witness.
On October 12, 1953, Additional District Magistrate ordered copies of applications and affidavits sent to District Judge for action against lawyers.
Criminal case No. 644 of 1953 against Revashankar under s.497 IPC started on complaint of Ganga Ram before Additional City Magistrate, Circle No. 2.

On December 17, 1953, Revashankar filed application under s.528 CrPC in court of Additional District Magistrate N.K. Acharya in Criminal Case No. 637/1953, containing aspersions: (1) Magistrate favouring Uma Shankar Chaturvedi; (2) no impartial justice; (3) Magistrate conspired with Mohan Singh and Uma Shankar re ornaments to implicate Revashankar and brother in theft; (4) Uma Shankar paid Rs.500 bribe to Magistrate via Ganga Ram.
Aspersions repeated in affidavit filed by Revashankar on December 21, 1953.
On January 11, 1954, Magistrate N.K. Acharya reported facts to Registrar of Madhya Bharat High Court for action against Revashankar for contempt.
High Court issued notice to Revashankar; Criminal Miscellaneous Application No. 2 of 1954 started. Revashankar showed cause on March 3, 1954.
On February 9, 1955, Division Bench (Newaskar and Samvatsar JJ.) held jurisdiction ousted under s.32 Contempt of Courts Act as act constituted offence under s.228 IPC.
Magistrate denied aspersions: did not know Revashankar or brother; no acquaintance.
Appeal filed by State of Madhya Bharat (substituted by State of Madhya Pradesh).

legal_issues.text: Whether the High Court was correct in holding that the act of the respondent constituted an offence under s.228 IPC, ousting jurisdiction under s.32 Contempt of Courts Act, 1952.

petitioner_arguments.text: Allegations in transfer application and affidavit are serious, scandalise the Court, create distrust in public mind, pollute stream of justice; not mere personal insult but beyond, so High Court jurisdiction not ousted.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.32 Contempt of Courts Act, 1952; Narotam Das v. Emperor AIR 1943 All 97; L.R. 1941 Nagpur 304; Emperor v. Jagnath Prasad Swadhiry LR 1938 All 548; ILR 12 Patna 1; ILR 12 Patna 172

petitioner_arguments.text: No intention to insult under s.228 IPC; primary object was transfer. Earlier Allahabad cases support no offence under s.228 where scandalous allegations in transfer app.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.228 IPC; Narotam Das v. Emperor AIR 1943 All 97

petitioner_arguments.text: Magistrate conscious of s.228 powers but referred to High Court as aspersions grave.
Doubts on intention to insult, whether insult offered, whether during judicial proceeding; if any essential lacking, no s.228 offence, but clear contempt apart from s.228.

respondent_arguments.text: Act intentionally offers personal insult to Magistrate, offence under s.228 IPC, ousts High Court jurisdiction under s.32 Act. Supported by Supreme Court cases.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.32 Contempt of Courts Act, 1952; s.228 IPC; 1952 SCR 425; 1953 SCR 1169; 1922 ILR 46 Bom 973

respondent_arguments.text: Every insult to Court is contempt punishable under s.228 IPC; no two kinds of contempt.

court_reasoning.text: s.32 Act ousts jurisdiction only where contempt is offence punishable as contempt under specific IPC provisions (ss.175,178,179,180,228), not other offences.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court jurisdiction excluded only for acts punishable as contempt under those IPC sections.

court_reasoning.text: s.228 IPC requires: (1) intention, (2) insult/interruption to public servant, (3) during stage of judicial proceeding. Uncertain if Magistrate sitting in judicial proceeding when app/affidavit filed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Third ingredient may not be fulfilled.

court_reasoning.text: Aspersions prima facie more than mere personal insult: scandalise court, create distrust, impair confidence in courts (conspiracy to implicate in false theft, bribe of Rs.500).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Act is scandalising court itself, not mere s.228 insult.

court_reasoning.text: Object of contempt: protect public interest in administration of justice, not judges personally. Scandalising attacks court authority.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Aspersions tend to create distrust in popular mind.

court_reasoning.text: Intention under s.228 depends on facts; no hard rule for transfer apps with defamatory assertions.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Here, aspersions at face value show more than intentional personal insult.

holdings.text: High Court jurisdiction not ousted under s.32 Contempt of Courts Act; act more than s.228 IPC offence, constitutes scandalising court.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bathina Ramakrishna Reddy v. State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: s.23 (now s.32) ousts jurisdiction only if contempt punishable under specific IPC contempt provisions, not other offences.

precedents_cited.case_name: Brahma Prakash Sharma v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Object of contempt: protect public confidence in administration of justice; scandalising court creates distrust.
High Court relied; but tests for intention in transfer apps not fully correct; no inflexible rule.
s.228 does not oust High Court contempt jurisdiction for scandalous communications.
No intention to insult in transfer app with defamatory assertions; intent to procure transfer.
Similar to above; no intention to insult.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ambard v. Attorney-General for Trinidad and Tobago
precedents_cited.relevance: Criticism allowed if not imputing improper motives or impairing justice.

statutes_cited.name: Contempt of Courts Act, 1952
statutes_cited.relevance: s.32 ousts High Court jurisdiction for subordinate court contempt if punishable as IPC contempt offence; s.4 punishment.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code, 1860
statutes_cited.relevance: s.228: intentional insult during judicial proceeding; specific contempt offence.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: s.528 transfer; s.480 empowers courts to punish IPC contempts summarily.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court order dated February 9, 1955 set aside. High Court has jurisdiction under Contempt of Courts Act; matter remitted to High Court for decision on merits.
outcome.relief_granted: Set aside High Court order; remit to High Court for merits.

key_quotes.text: "the sub-section referred to above excludes the jurisdiction of High Court only in cases where the acts alleged to constitute contempt of a subordinate court are punishable as contempt under specific provisions of the Indian Penal Code"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Interprets s.32 Contempt Act from Ramakrishna Reddy case.

key_quotes.text: "It would be only repeating what has been said so often by various Judges that the object of contempt proceedings is not to afford protection to Judges personally... but a protection to the public whose interests would be very much affected if... the authority of the court is lowered"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines purpose of contempt from Brahma Prakash Sharma.

key_quotes.text: "the aspersions made therein prima facie showed that they were much more than a mere insult to the learned Magistrate in effect, they scandalised the Court in such a way as to create distrust in the popular mind"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core finding why not mere s.228 offence.
